claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination significantly broadens the repertoire of tumor antigens presented on MHC-I molecules.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape

claims.caveat: The immunopeptidomic analysis was performed in mouse models, and while robust, may not perfectly reflect the human tumor microenvironment.

claims.claim: The mechanism by which intratumoral mRNA sensitizes tumors to ICI is dependent on the induction of Type I interferon signaling pathways.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: The direct causal link was proven using an antibody blockade control in the preclinical mouse model, not in the human retrospective cohort.

claims.claim: The combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccination and anti-PD-L1 therapy leads to increased immune cell infiltration and improved tumor control compared to either monotherapy.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy
Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.

claims.caveat: Efficacy experiments were conducted in murine models, and the retrospective human data suggesting benefit is prone to residual confounding.

claims.claim: Patients who received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination showed a statistically improved survival outcome when subsequently treated with immune checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: This finding is subject to significant validity threats as the human analysis is retrospective, non-randomized, and complicated by heterogeneity in tumor types and treatment history.
